issue.title: Ability to sort works on Author pages alphabetically

labels.name: Type: Feature Request
labels.description: Issue describes a feature or enhancement we'd like to implement. [managed]

labels.name: Theme: Search
labels.description: Issues related to search UI and backend. [managed]

labels.name: Priority: 3
labels.description: Issues that we can consider at our leisure. [managed]

labels.name: Good First Issue
labels.description: Easy issue. Good for newcomers. [managed]

labels.name: hacktoberfest
labels.description: Issues appropriate for Hacktoberfest participants

labels.name: Affects: UI
labels.description: Issues with the web site's user interface. [managed]

labels.name: Affects: Librarians
labels.description: Issues related to features that librarians particularly need. [managed]

labels.name: Lead: @cdrini
labels.description: Issues overseen by Drini (Staff: Team Lead & Solr, Library Explorer, i18n) [managed]

issue.body:
It is possible by manually appending `?sort=title` to the URL like so:
https://openlibrary.org/authors/OL1394244A/Cory_Doctorow?sort=title

However, we should add it to the UI so that patrons can easily do this.
It would also help for people working on merges.

On the authors page we can add a link next to `| Top Rated` that says one of the following:
- `A-Z`
- `Title`
- `Alphabetical`

A separate issue would be to add this to the main books + authors page.

comment.body:
The `?sort=title workaround` is very handy, and I'm pleasantly surprised that it appears to be doing a multi-lingual title sort, ignoring "the", "el" and others at the start, which makes it much easier to find duplicate works.

I'm assuming this is being done automatically by solr, but had noticed that the title_sort values returned in search.json don't seem to reflect this. Is that a bug?

https://openlibrary.org/search.json?q=the+wind+in+the+willows&fields=title_suggest,title_sort

issue.title: Allow creation of lists via hand-crafted links of seed items

labels.name: Type: Feature Request
labels.description: Issue describes a feature or enhancement we'd like to implement. [managed]

labels.name: Theme: Lists
labels.description: Issues related to reading Lists

labels.name: Priority: 2
labels.description: Important, as time permits. [managed]

labels.name: Lead: @cdrini
labels.description: Issues overseen by Drini (Staff: Team Lead & Solr, Library Explorer, i18n) [managed]

issue.body:
A link like the following (you may need to change the username in the url to your own) will pre-populate the add a list page with the specified items:

https://openlibrary.org/people/davidscotson/lists/add?name=The+Murderbot+Diaries&seeds=OL24747433W,OL17914663W,OL27481052W,OL19753589W,OL26794585W,OL24349461W,OL20735675W,OL20805971W,OL33402895W

This superficially looks the same as if you visited the "add a list" url and manually added the items. But on saving you get a 500 error if you use the url method.

On investigation, I believe this is due to the HTML form not specifying an "action" attribute, and so it tries to POST the form the to the full url, rather than just "https://openlibrary.org/people/davidscotson/lists/add".

Adding that shorter url to the <form> as an action attribute makes this work again.

### Details

- **Logged in (Y/N)?** Y

- **Environment (prod/dev/local)?** prod
<!-- If not sure, put prod -->

### Stakeholders
<!-- @ tag stakeholders of this bug -->

comment.body: What a headache! Took me so long to figure out what the root issue was, but I think I have a better fix here: https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/pull/8463 .

issue.title: Wikidata <> authors integration: first steps

labels.name: Priority: 1
labels.description: Do this week, receiving emails, time sensitive, . [managed]

labels.name: Needs: Review
labels.description: This issue/PR needs to be reviewed in order to be closed or merged (see comments). [managed]

issue.body:
[Document with the goal of this project](https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/wiki/Wikidata-Integration) v0 goals: - to start pulling wikidata into the database and showing something basic - Upstream code class Author —> Add get_wikidata - Should Fetch from wikidata based on parameter. Otherwise only check wikidata_cache table - Author edit/view templates will call this - Render_wikidata_infobox method for rending the wikidata author box Next steps: - Decide on a bulk import method - Enrich the infobox - Use wikidata for author autocomplete ### Technical Trying to keep it as simple as possible. The wikidata method is on the authors model because works/editions store wikidata IDs differently so we'll have to handle that when we get there. My current coals is just authors. ### Testing Add a wikidata ID to an author and then you'll start seeing this "short description" field showing up on the side. ### Screenshot
Aug 30 demo video (slightly outdated), see below https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/assets/921217/509cdf8c-770d-4836-a8e2-631f468b32e3
September 2 screenshot (most recent)
### Stakeholders @cdrini

comment.body: Hey Charles! I've read through your feedback and am thinking on how to best respond. But regardless I'm sorry the process has made you feel frustrated; not at all the intention! Thank you for taking the time to write your thoughts.

commits.message:
Add support for safe mode blur in CSS and macro

Adds preliminary support for book covers to be blurred when a user enters safe mode by adding two new classes to the search result item CSS that are inserted into the SearchResultsWork macro when safe mode is on (currently set to True with a placeholder variable)

Blur covers according to safe mode cookie

Improves implementation of cover blurring: blurs covers if the user has enabled safe mode (checked by getting the value of the sfw cookie), but does not check whether a book has content warnings before blurring it.

Add a check for sfw cookie in work search

If the value of the web cookie is retrieved as 'yes', this will retrieve the subject keys during do_search() which will either have the content warning or not and can be blurred appropriately. If the cookie is not 'yes' it will not retrieve the subjects.

Blur book covers on search page in safe mode

Adds support for blurring book covers on the search page when the user is in safe mode. Any work whose subject_key as returned by do_search contains a subject beginning with content_warning will have its cover blurred, if the user is in safe mode. Preview covers are also affected by blur.

Fix template error when searching without safe mode

Fixes an issue where content warnings would be retrieved even when do_search had not return subject keys for the list of documents, leading to a template error. Now, content warning is only searched for if the user has safe mode enabled.

pull_request.title: Fix Storybook after upgrade
pull_request.body:
<!-- What does this PR achieve? [feature|hotfix|fix|refactor] -->
Recent Webpack upgrades broke Storybook.  This PR updates our Storybook code such that stories can be served on developer's local machines.  The GitHub action which automatically deploys our Storybook instance to GitHub pages was removed, as it is obsolete.  A new deployment action will be added in another PR.

### Technical
<!-- What should be noted about the implementation? -->

### Testing
<!-- Steps for reviewer to reproduce/verify what this PR does/fixes. -->

### Screenshot
<!-- If this PR touches UI, please post evidence (screenshots) of it behaving correctly. -->

### Stakeholders

issue.title: Video Tutorial of Implementing a Trusted Book Provider (e.g. Cita Press)

labels.name: Type: Feature Request
labels.description: Issue describes a feature or enhancement we'd like to implement. [managed]

labels.name: Module: Import
labels.description: Issues related to the configuration or use of importbot and other bulk import systems. [managed]

labels.name: Priority: 2
labels.description: Important, as time permits. [managed]

labels.name: Needs: Help
labels.description: Issues, typically substantial ones, that need a dedicated developer to take them on. [managed]

labels.name: Lead: @cdrini
labels.description: Issues overseen by Drini (Staff: Team Lead & Solr, Library Explorer, i18n) [managed]

issue.body:
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...] -->
### Background

OpenLibrary.org is a catalog of every book published and where possible, it links to sources where you can access books to read or borrow.

Many of these books are fulfilled by the Internet Archive's book lending library program. In addition, Open Library links to many vetted partner book sources like Project Gutenberg, Librivox, Standard Ebooks, OpenStax, and others through what it calls its Trusted Book Providers (TBP) program.

We have a [form](https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdufB9B1aX9RceKLycbxJBW9bv9EJv_PEiVNu8cXycXdD134A/viewform) where organizations can apply to be considered for the TBP program.

Currently, each TBP is added to the website manually and this involves a few steps.
1. Writing a python script to load the metadata from the partner into a format that can be imported into Open Library
2. Extending the Open Library TBP code to register a new source
3. Using the openlibrary-client with step [1] to submit these records for import

The program is detailed here: https://openlibrary.org/trusted-book-providers. There's also a blog post [here](https://blog.openlibrary.org/2021/12/20/introducing-trusted-book-providers/) with more details.

### Describe the problem that you'd like solved
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you want to happen. -->

Something that would be really helpful is a video recording of implementing a Trusted Book Provider. It should only take 1h (assuming the data is all in one place). Citapress may be a good place to start. Once we have a single example, others should be able to relatively easily add new sources which could make a big impact.

We have permission from Cita to pursue and integration and all their data and books are available from citapress.org and http://citapress.org/page-data/index/page-data/json

### Additional context
<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. -->

Here's a script which fetches the publisher's catalog and begins to map Cita press's books (http://citapress.org/page-data/index/page-data/json) to Open Library's import schema (https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary-client/blob/master/olclient/schemata/import.schema.json):

```
import requests

r = requests.get('https://citapress.org/page-data/index/page-data.json')
data = r.json() # we load the fetched website data into python as json which we can manipulate like a dictionary
books = data['result']['data']['allMarkdownRemark']['nodes']

# We need these books to be converted into this format: https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary-client/blob/master/olclient/schemata/import.schema.json
for book in books:
  openlibrary_book = {
      'title': book['frontmatter']['title'],
      'description': book['frontmatter']['description'],
      'cover': '???',
      "source_records": 'citapress',  # ignore, leave as is :)
      "authors": [],  # might be missing from the data!
      "publishers": [],
      "publish_date": ''
  }
  print(openlibrary_book)
```

### Examples & References
Here's an example of importing...

* Pressbooks: https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/pull/6582/files
* Project Gutenberg, Librivox, & Standard Ebooks: https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/pull/5271/files
* OpenStax: https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/pull/6138/files

### Stakeholders
<!-- @ tag stakeholders of this bug -->

forkee.name: openlibrary
forkee.description: One webpage for every book ever published!

### Stakeholders @cdrini

comment.body:
Responding because my name was mentioned again.

I still don't understand this PR / Wikidata project at all.

The existence of a Wikipedia database in Open Library _at all_ seems like a giant red flag to me, but from reading the available docs I can't point to anything specific.

From the first 2 lines of this PR
 > v0 goals:
>    to start pulling wikidata into the database and showing something basic

@tfmorris 's concerns about DDOS seem valid, I don't think the doc says anything about the scale. 

@cdrini 's comment about "only on user request" seems to mitigate that risk, but left me thinking what's the point of only storing a partial mirror of Wikidata on OL? Is it for web caching popular author pages responses? Maybe you should consider using web caching technology to achieve the same goal (please don't take that a serious suggestion, because I don't think that's the problem here).

The doc doesn't really give any indication why we need a database. From reading the linked doc https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/wiki/Wikidata-Integration  the most concrete usecase and functional suggestion I could extract from it was the UI change to the Open Library author pages where an Open Library patron might want to see the corresponding data from Wikidata, side by side.

I'd say the core usecase covered by this "As an Open Library patron looking at a Open Library author page, I might be curious as to how this author is represented on a different website: Wikidata" is 100% satisfied by having the Wikidata link as part of our author metadata, so no action is required.

But from @cdrini's recent comment, it looks like it's only meant to be on the _edit_ page, so only librarians are meant to see this. I had a whole set of thoughts based on reading the document on how it was a bit pointless displaying a different variant to all patrons. It makes a little more sense if the use case is now revealed to be for helping librarians make metadata improvements, but that info wasn't available when this PR started, or when the document was created, so how could we constructively evaluate it against that purpose?

Anyway, based on my original reading of the doc and the recent revealed details:

* There seems no point doing a fragmentary mirror of Wikidata (apparently that is not being suggested, but it wasn't clear)
* It's apparently obvious that doing a full network fetch of Wikidata is a bad idea (that wasn't clear)
* The sensible way to do a full Wikidata db population into a SQL db on a different website with a different purpose is via db dumps... (nothing in the doc says or implies we need it or that's how it was going to be done)
.....
* Then what is the point of fetching _any_ data live on user request?

You'll probably tell me that it's obviously to get the latest data and keep it fresh, in which case what is the point of storing any of it in the database at all.... and why is that even important?

The point is we'll have to have a silly argument about databases when none of this stuff is at all obvious from the docs I was asked to read, and _requires_ a real time discussion to make any sense of it, and even then nothing is clear as to how any of it relates to improving anything to with Wikidata / OL integration, or even is the best way to achieve the minor but concrete UI changes that might (or might not!) be driving all of this development.

After reading the doc and establishing the only concrete suggestion were some small UI changes, I had specific concerns that the changes wouldn't be useful as there are only a few possibilities:

* The metadata is exactly the same
* The metadata is wildly different
* The metadata differs in trivial ways 

The doc gave no indication of what might be done in each case. I don't think it's at all obvious, other than in many cases it'll be "do nothing", and in others (perhaps considerably fewer) the appropriate action will be very specific and depend on other factors not even touched on here.

I also had some concerns about practicalities and licensing of the (reading between the lines using my knowledge of the two systems) the only two shared datafields that are likely to have any impact on OL -- images and descriptions....

but why would I bring _any_ of this up on a PR clearly about database implementation? Talking about UIs on a database PR is completely off topic....  And when the UI suggestion is sort of hedged as "maybe" example of what this integration will bring as we're only at "stage 0" I'm going to be jumping the gun to be talking about such details... Turns out I was slightly wrong anyway as it's apparently an edit page feature for a smaller group of users anyway, which puts a different spin on things.

Sorry if I'm sounding negative, but I am feeling quite a bit of frustration with these recent "stage 0" general efforts do do "something" leading with a big technical implementation which promises to change literally nothing at first (seemingly to counter any possible criticism) to open a whole range of future possibilities that we'll cover later. There's temptation to review in good faith a provide helpful suggestions, and then at least check that there are no unintended consequences, but most of that comes down to mechanical line length checking and whether the variables are clearly named.

The docs that exist are all about maybe possibilities and there's so much ambiguity it's impossible to offer any concrete evaluation of a "solution". I'm not just talking about this now, I had similar issues with the subject tags project, which again seemed like possibly relatively minor UI changes driving large code changes, but I had even less context to offer any comment, and the whole thing seemed designed to avoid any good faith critical interaction with it.

Now I don't know if I'm supposed to be talking about databases (I really don't want to be), efficient use of network requests, or specific UI details, but have the strong impression that anything I want to talk about driven by a desire to improve  Wikidata / OL integration can easily now be dismissed as off-topic noise on this PR and project, and that's the most frustrating thing about this is that now presumably multiple people clearly sharing the same goal to make better use of Wikidata are going to be reduced to arguing about irrelevant details.

**The structure of these implementation-first efforts are not conducive to canvasing constructive feedback. The use of the term "Stage 0" appears to be a indicator of this sort of thing.**

@tfmorris suggestions about going the other way, from Wikidata to OL seem more valuable to me, I'd consider a browser plugin to help librarians edit OL author pages if that's what we're trying to do... I also have thoughts about what you might expect to see given what I know about how OL got Wikidata QIDs (my historical bot matching, the Wikidata Mix'n'Match tool, and the actions of Wikidata editors)... but all these things seem explicitly not relevant to what's being discussed here.

Some concrete suggestions / alternatives which are on-topic for this PR:

* Try-it-and-see db mirrors of all of Wikidata are probably better suited to stand-alone projects and not part of OL's core codebase (in my opinion)
* Come up with a better post-hoc reason why OL needs a database named Wikidata
* Consider addressing Librarian UI editing issues directly, what OL  usecases require particular Author metadata and how these are not met currently, and how Wikidata might help by going back to planning stages and figuring out what will be impactful, and what is available. 

Apologies again for sounding negative, but I keep getting pinged on this and I would like to help make OL / Wikidata better, but the way this is set up I feel trapped, my other option would be to err on the side of just not saying anything (like I did for subject tags). I know I don't need to understand everything, but I'm also not going to review all code just because it exists. My problem here is really with the implementation-first trend, and while I'd like to talk about Wikidata, I'm not even sure where to begin here.

issue.title: Redirect /advanced to /advancedsearch

labels.name: Type: Feature Request
labels.description: Issue describes a feature or enhancement we'd like to implement. [managed]

labels.name: Priority: 4
labels.description: An issue, but should be worked on when no other pressing work can be done. [managed]

labels.name: Lead: @mekarpeles
labels.description: Issues overseen by Mek (Staff: Program Lead) [managed]

issue.body:
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the problem is. Ex. I'm always frustrated when [...] -->

### Describe the problem that you'd like solved
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you want to happen. -->
While Googling for something on OL I came across https://openlibrary.org/advanced which seems to be just an old version of https://openlibrary.org/advancedsearch 

I was a bit confused at first because I knew the advanced search page should look different and realized it is a different page.

### Proposal & Constraints
<!-- What is the proposed solution / implementation? Is there a precedent of this approach succeeding elsewhere? -->
Redirect that page to /advancedsearch

<!-- Which suggestions or requirements should be considered for how feature needs to appear or be implemented? -->

### Additional context
<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. -->
I can't seem to find this anywhere in the code base so maybe an admin needs to change the page.

@mekarpeles: Here's where /advancedsearch is defined in the code
https://github.com/internetarchive/openlibrary/blob/master/openlibrary/plugins/worksearch/code.py#L515-L519
It's possible that https://openlibrary.org/advanced?m=edit is an infogami page which needs to be converted into a redirect
### Stakeholders
<!-- @ tag stakeholders of this bug -->

comment.body: @RayBB `/advanced` is already redirecting to `/advancedsearch`. I think its fixed now.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -613,7 +613,7 @@
- $ weight = book.get_weight() or storage(value="", units="grams") + $ weight = book.get_weight() or storage(value="", units="kilos")
comment.body:
The default weight should perhaps be grams; that's what other sites use and a more reasonable default than kg for books.

```suggestion
                    $ weight = book.get_weight() or storage(value="", units="grams")
```

pull_request.title: Make Metric System as Default for Physical Values of the Book.
pull_request.body:
<!-- What issue does this PR close? -->
Closes #2242 

<!-- What does this PR achieve? [feature|hotfix|fix|refactor] -->
Make the Metric System as Default for Physical Values of the Book while editing. Most comments in the issue favored the metric system so went with the metric.

### Technical
<!-- What should be noted about the implementation? -->
Not that much technical, just changed the default to `centimeters` from `inches` and to `kilos` from `grams`.

### Testing
<!-- Steps for reviewer to reproduce/verify what this PR does/fixes. -->
`docker-compose exec web make test` returned no errors.


### Screenshot
<!-- If this PR touches UI, please post evidence (screenshots) of it behaving correctly. -->
![Screenshot from 2020-11-21 03-52-50](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/57295877/99855954-f7b36d80-2bad-11eb-8f77-5224f9554b74.png)

### Stakeholders
<!-- @ tag stakeholders of this bug -->
@seabelis @cdrini
